The Fontaine de la PaixÂ (orÂ Fontaine de la Paix et des Arts) is a fountain located in theÂ promenade of the AllÃ©e du SÃ©minaire-Jean-Jacques-OlierÂ which runs along theÂ rue BonaparteÂ in theÂ 6th arrondissement of Paris, not far from the Place Saint-Sulpice. This fountain is one of theÂ 15 fountainsÂ that were to be put into service in Paris after the completion of theÂ Ourcq canal. The architect Destournelles had designed it to be built on theÂ Place du ChateletÂ at the request of Napoleon IÂ to commemorate theÂ Peace Treaty of Amiens, but in 1807, it was decided to build it on the outskirts of theÂ Place Saint-Sulpice . It only remained there until 1824, the year when it was relegated to theÂ Saint-Germain market, the imposingÂ Saint-Sulpice fountainÂ having to occupy the center of the square. In 1935, it was moved again to occupy its current location, in the AllÃ©e du SÃ©minaire, an open, wooded garden which slopes down to theÂ rue de VaugirardÂ on the odd side of rue Bonaparte. This alley had just been created by the destruction of the buildings of the Community of Daughters of Christian Instruction. It is a fountain in a neoclassical style, very close to the Fountain of Mars which dates from the same period. A square massif topped with triangular pediments is placed in the center of a square basin. The four faces are decorated with allegorical bas-reliefs by the sculptor Jean-Joseph Espercieux which represent Agriculture, Commerce, Science and the Arts and Peace. On two opposite sides, a basin in the shape of a clam shell collects water coming from an orifice before it flows into the general basin surrounding the fountain.
A very pretty fountain, very classic, very elegant, and which has just been renovated.
